Exaggerate: The claim exaggerates the size of the catfish caught, as the photo has been edited to make it appear larger.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient evidence or support to back up the existence of a 736-pound Giant Mekong catfish in the Mississippi River.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the catfish caught is a Giant Mekong catfish, despite the fact that they are native to the Mekong River in Southeast Asia and have never been seen in the United States.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that the photo accompanying the article is of a flathead catfish, which is native to the Mississippi River and does not grow to be more than 123 pounds.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the claim is an April Fools' Day prank, as the article was published on April 1, 2016.
Falters at times: The claim falters in terms of credibility and accuracy, as it relies on a four-year-old story that has gained recent traffic on Facebook.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement bias in the provided claim.
